You made some interesting comments about the history and dangers of the scientific process itself. However, the reason that you think the authors missed the point, is because your point is not what they were writing about. They were not writing about the scientific process, but about the dangers of believing in pseudoscience.

A more relevant comment would be that they did not talk about the dangers of knowing the truth. Nuclear weapons are the classic example of this, but there are many more in all fields of science.

Pointing out the dangers of pseudoscience is far from claiming that actual science is danger-free. It does seem fair to say that in the long run, the dangers of pseudoscience are more dangerous. Of course, effective technologies can be much more devastating than ineffective ones when used carelessly or with evil intent. But that only illustrates the dangers of ignorance, not science.

This article was disappointing. How can people (the authors here) get it so right and so wrong at the same time? And philosophers at that! The correct part is of course the part about being skeptical about things yet willing to try things out and see if they work--which is to say apply reason and the scientific method. But here is where the writers go mind-bogglingly wrong: They speak of the "dangers" of pseudoscience--the article itself has as its heading "The dangers of pseudoscience". Why is that wrong, even ridiculous? The answer is simple: To do science itself is dangerous; we must risk even death in many trials and errors to achieve scientific certainty.

Examine the history of science. Examine what men of science actually did. Examples such as Newton poking around with his eyeball; Koller putting cocaine in his eye as a final experiment to see if it would work in eye surgery; Curie damaging herself in her experiments. The list goes on. The Wright brothers trying to get off the ground for God's sake! Pseudoscience is not bad because it is dangerous, it is bad because we remain in ignorance and danger rather than risk danger in the search for truth. How can these philosophers here not understand that? Have they not heard of art either or business? You cannot succeed unless you take a chance...

The question is not danger of pseudoscience but whether ignorance will be overcome in bravery of science, experimentation, adventure--cultivation of correct dangerous road.

@Matthew Carnicelli,
The claim of arrogance is often leveled against scientists by people who claim to be aware of mystical worlds that the rest of us cannot see. The reality is that scientists can't just say anything they please, make predictions after the fact or make claims based on personal revelation. Scientific facts fit into a rigid framework of knowledge that has to be demonstrable, and that corresponds to reality. A scientist is lucky to discover one new fact about the universe in a lifetime of study and research. The body of knowledge that we currently possess took centuries of hard work. But If mystical, unseen forces really do affect the mundane details of our lives, then everything we know about the world is wrong. If the word arrogance has any meaning, it should be applied to those who would dismiss centuries of hard-won understanding based on worldviews that merely assuage their particular insecurities. Science can be corrupted by corporate greed and drug company excesses, but they are as much enemies of science as are other mystics and charlatans. Their actions discredit themselves, not the scientific method.

Workerbee: It is true that thousands of people die every year because of medication or other errors (although the exact numbers are in dispute). However, I would be interested to see the data about the number of people who die because of adverse reactions to medications that are correctly prescribed and taken. It would also be important, though difficult, to compare that to the number of people who would have died from their disease if they were not treated with appropriate medication. If you have such data, I would be interested to see it. If not, your claim is vacuous.

Most, but not all, "alternative" medicine does no harm (other than keeping people away from effective treatment), but it also does no good - other than the placebo effect. Scientifically validated medical treatments do varying amounts of good - from the undisputed benefit of antibiotics to the probable benefit of many newer medications. As a physician I generally avoid newer medication, because the profit motive driving the medical-industrial complex has distorted medical information so much that it is impossible to know whether a new, highly-touted medication will do more good than harm. However, I never recommend alternative medicine, because I don't feel right about recommending something that I have no reason to believe will be effective.

J Anthony: Your statement as to the U.S. not always having borrowed money is patently false. Alexander Hamilton, you may have heard of him, in the early 1790s in trying to get the federal financial house in order insisted it was important that the gvt. borrow money, for the same reason people today need to have some debt, in order to build credit. Along with that, of course, he also insisted the gvt needed to honor that debt. Few other institutions in the world (the old Bank of England?) have over the past 200+ years established such a credit rating as the U.S. federal gvt. And it is precisely that credit which a default would trash. "Say, honey, since you won't rein in your spending, I'm going to stop paying our credit card bills. Yeah, it'll ruin our credit rating, but that'll teach ya!"

Then there are the deniers who believe nothing dire will happen. In fact just the possibility of a default is already costing business extra expenses. The cost of short term borrowing in the repo market has risen. This is where companies borrow in many cases using their bonds as collateral. They do this to make payroll and other daily debt, rather than liquidating their equities which are paying higher interest than the loans cost.
Treasury holders will most likely expect the U.S. to eventually make good on its debt, but they know they will have to wait to collect, and they will have to borrow to replace the income lost at the time. That will drive up the cost of the U.S. selling treasuries at a later date as the buyers will want to make up any losses.

We know the country can not function economically without borrowing. Like it or not, that is a fact. It can reduce the amount borrowed, but it will have to collect more income to do so, that means by taxes.The GOP and its proselytes will fight any such legislation. You can't prove that it does, either - science rarely "proves" something, especially at this level of complexity.

In fact, in scientific studies of medical effectiveness, we never try to show that something doesn't work. Instead, we assume it doesn't work until there is good evidence that it does. Statistically, we require evidence to reject the null hypothesis.

That's not science! That's a statistical analysis that can become part of science, if it's part of testing formal mathematical models with external and internal validity. But by itself, it can be just as much witchcraft, given that if you fail to have a scientific theory that you're developing, you can never be sure you've used the proper controls.

It's not straight-forward at all. If you want to do science and have the certainty of science, you have to actually do science, which means lots and lots of math interlinking underlying mechanisms with empirical measurements that can then give you real testability. Running statistical analysis can get you past the FDA --- but it doesn't make it any less witchcraft which lies upon the illusion of "correlation means causation".

"In this sense, there is no such thing as “alternative” medicine, there’s only stuff that works and stuff that doesn’t." .......It is really straight forward, you do a double blind study with a defined or measurable end point. Neither the patient nor the observer who evaluates the results knows whether the treatment being given is intended to be real or is designed to be a sham. When the code is broken if the treatment is valid the affect will be mathematically significant. And in the end remember, you cannot prove that something doesn't work, you can only prove that it does.

To Bethany 1:57pm,

Actually there are many statements in the article attributing realizations to the eleven-year-olds: "Already our daughter knows how to dig deep"; "Like us, she values expertise and excellence"; "They respect the uniform"; " [soccer] keeps them from being complacent"; "They understand that there is always more out there"; etc.

This is a lot of pressure. Eleven-year-olds aren't Marines, or management trainees. They don't express themselves in these terms; it's the parents' wishful thinking that imposes them.

Coupled with the statements that "there's no off season", and that on a tournament weekend, "There's nothing else", the stance expressed in this article is really disturbing. Professional and college athletes get seasons off.

I don't think you understand  that it's what her daughter loves. There are kids who just love being so competitive and they love mastering a skill. My daughter also plays competitive soccer and the more she plays, the more she loves it. The better she gets at it, the more fun she gets out of it. And she's not even the most competitive girls on her team. Just as the author stated, the kids have to be really into it, to play so much, so constantly. No parent could supply the drive, it has to be in them. My daughter would play soccer all the time, but I do worry about the overuse injuries, so I sign her up for swimming in the summer, and she does a theater camp. But soccer starts again in the middle of July, and then it's on, on, on. It's a lot of fun, even if a bit exhausting.
Chill out on this, parents attributing their own values to their children. I once met a baby of about six months old whose mother explained, "she is a vegetarian."

I can hardly believe that the subject of this essay is an eleven-year-old. No eleven-year-old realizes all the insights this mother is attributing to her, or has seen enough of the world to make one particular structured team sport this kind of all-consuming activity. It isn't even the way to develop a great soccer player: those develop through lots of free play and a variety of physical activity (cross-training if you will).

I write as the parent of a D-1 athlete who took up her sport for the first time in high school, for fun, and turned out to be a natural ~ successful in part because she had learned from a variety of athletic endeavors pursued casually and free-forml, and because she had a relaxed attitude and strengths in many other areas, academic, social, musical. Moreover, as the college coach observed, she was not already burned out.
